title: Have you read anything good recently? - Quora

response.answer_text: Have I read anything good recently? You bet I have! When I came upon this question I was thrilled at the opportunity to share some GREAT NEWS with my friends. And with all the other people here who are in love with reading and books. . . . First, some quick background: When I worked part time at Barnes and Noble, our employee discount was 30%, which was increased to 40% during the Christmas season. Sweet! Everyone received books from me including my grandchildren, who were little ones at the time except for my oldest granddaughter. Well, they all got books even before and after I worked there. When my step-grandson Mason was six years old I gave him a hardcover boxed set of the complete Harry Potter books. You know, for when he was old enough to read them. That time came and he completely devoured them. He has since become an avid, eager reader. His mom, my stepdaughter Rachael, gives me credit for that. It's wonderful, but I can't accept all the credit. Great books and great storytelling deserve much of it of course. As does my husband, his Yale educated Grandpa. They've both read Dostoyevsky. Me? I can't even get past the names. Imagine my joy when, about two years ago, Mason announced that he wants to be a writer. He's now 15 and has had some practice. Many essays for school assignments, a few short stories, including one about his parent's divorce. Broke my heart. He often emails them to his Grandpa and me for critique or advice. He's good. He's really, really good. So, the GREAT NEWS? Mason wrote a poem that's going to be published in an anthology of The Live Poet Society of NJ. He's one of only 100 chosen in a NATIONWIDE contest! His beautiful poem was selected and all 100 will be published shortly. The anthology is called American High School: Just Poetry. The talented young poets then go on to compete and one winning student receives five-hundred dollars in scholarship money. They're all winners in my book. Rachael texted me this news yesterday. At the end she said “All your literary support paid off …” **Sniffle sniffle** I called my grandson to gush. Along with my blubbering congratulations I said “Mason, I couldn't be more proud of you. Your mom tells me I had something to do with it, and that makes me happy". With the slightly cocky swagger that only a 15-year-old boy can produce with his voice, he replied “Oh yeah. A hundred percent, Gramma D, a hundred percent, definitely. Yeah. The Harry Potter books. Yeah. Definitely.” It was then that I handed the phone to his Grandpa. I was gonna start blubbering again. He emailed us his poem. That just happens to be the “anything good" I've read recently. It is stunning. Mason James Bryant, my grandson. His name even sounds literary, doesn't it?

I tend to read carefully and to apply lessons learned to my life - even when those lessons come from a novel. This proved to be the case with Tom Robbins’ Jitterbug Perfume, which I finished about six weeks ago. It would spoil the story if I told you why, but I now own a collection of essential oils, which I use for various fragrance, healing and cosmetic purposes, and am even more respectful of plants. I finished Never Too Late by Stella Atterbury two weeks ago, after reading it for the second time. It is a sort of autobiographical cookbook. Why I love it is firstly because she is a brave lady who jumped into the catering industry in mid-life and whose restaurant was listed in the Good Food Guide despite her lack of previous experience. Secondly, she had an innovative and highly practical approach to cookery. Years ago, when I had several children living at home, her methods enabled me to cope and feed them nutritious food on a tight budget. The recipes seem dated now, but the methods she developed are always applicable to a family or catering business. Atterbury was the person who is responsible for our cookers now having a low setting, and possibly for the whole slow cooker industry as well, although her name is not widely known. The third I have finished in the past month is Never Split the Difference: Negotiating as if Your Life Depended on It by Chris Voss, who is a former FBI hostage negotiator. I am still getting used to applying his advice to my everyday conversations. It works. People will tell me all sorts of things. I don’t have to ask what matters to them. They are grateful to be properly heard. Voss’ methods have also helped in areas of my life where reaching an agreement was essential. Books that aren’t good, I rarely finish. Also, “good” is in the eye of the reader, where books are concerned.

What’s the best thing that you read in the recent times? “The problem is that once we know something—say, the melody of a song—we find it hard to imagine not knowing it. Our knowledge has “cursed” us. We have difficulty sharing it with others, because we can’t readily re-create their state of mind.” The above lines are from a very insightful article titled – ‘The Curse of Knowledge’ written by Chip Heath and Dan Heath. It was originally published in the December 2006 issue of Harvard Business Review. This article is definitely the best thing read I have read in the recent times. Why did I like it so much? This ‘curse of knowledge’ that this article talks about is something that is at the root of most of the challenges that we experience in our daily lives with regards to our relationship with others. Most of the issues in our lives occur simply because – as the article says – ‘we have difficulty sharing it with others, because we can’t readily re-create their state of mind’. Although the article speaks in the context of the business world and its ‘enormous information imbalances’, I find it equally relevant beyond the business world. And how do we overcome this ‘curse’. The article does offer an interesting method of addressing it. It says: “Concrete language and stories defeat the curse of knowledge…” By the way, aren’t we all trying to do the same on Quora? You can read this brief but insightful article at this link: https://hbr.org/2006/12/the-curse-of-knowledge

Here is the synopsis of an awesome fantasy book I have recently read! Inside this book hides a magical world that is celebrating something special! It’s that time of year where every major city gathers for another Ascension Day. But this year it’s different. Inside, awaiting and resting, are Perry’s powers. On this day, he, his friends and everyone else who lives and breathes, can use their powers through the ceremony of a godlike light. But this day is different! Inside the White City there is an evil army. After the destruction of his home, Perry finds himself lost with his best friend, his sister and their servant, Bailey, an Ever who leads them to safety. Outside, on their journey, the group is forced to use their powers. But as time fades, so does their humanity! Releasing their gifts of life to the world, only leads to mutation. And what was, may never be, but this time it’s different! From the plains of the White City, Kelton Whide, to the forest of the Green City, Everbreen, nature takes its course. And where the Panda talks, a Masked Man mumbles and many white orchids turn to red, what is sacrificed inside this book leaves this magical world truely in awe! “The Gifts Of Life’ by Oliver Smuhar, is a young new author that has just won, The Reviewers Choice Award for ‘Best Book Written by an Author Age 18 or Under' and the '2018-2019 Global Award’ for Australia

I have. I’m really not hard to please with books, but since I have this A2A I’ll go into a bit more depth. Recently I have read: The Fifth Elephant - Terry PratchettThe Swarm - Orson Scott CardThe Rithmatist - Brandon SandersonNow, all three of these authors come in my top five favorite authors, so I knew they’d be good. But still, I was pleasantly surprised. I didn’t expect Brandon’s to be able to write anything as good as Mistborn and Stormlight - because surely one person can’t write too many amazing books! I was wrong. The magic system in The Rithmatist is probably my favorite ever, with geometry and mystery combined in an intriguing combo. The climax was a bit confusing - there were like three - but it was still a beautifully written book. I always seem to forget how good Terry Pratchett is, and The Fifth Elephant continued this trend. It was fantastically moralistic and powerful while still managing to incorporate comedy and a complex (kinda) plot. The Swarm was basically what I expected. OSC is nothing if not consistent.

Audrey Nethery, from Kentucky, suffers from Diamond Blackfan Anemia(DBA)The youngster has already undergone 20 blood transfusions because her body doesn't produce enough red blood cellsA video of Audrey dancing at her Zumba class has had nearly three million views and raised vital funds for the Diamond Blackfan Anemia Foundation. The parents of a sweet six-year-old are using adorable videos of their daughter dancing to help raise awareness about her rare disorder - and the moving and grooving clips have quickly turned the youngster into an online star. But the condition doesn't stop Audrey from dancing, which she does incredibly well to Bruno Mars’ chart-topping hit Uptown Funk in a widely-watched video that her family posted on her Facebook page.  She was also born with a hole in her heart. But despite her hurdles, her father Scott told Daily Mail Online, she has plenty of energy and a positive outlook: 'Audrey is a happy, loving, smart, little girl who loves to dance, listen to music, and collect dolls and stuffed animals. She is incredibly strong and leaves an impression on everyone she meets!'  But Audrey's cute videos don't just bring joy to those who watch them - they also help bring attention to DBA and raise funds for the Diamond Blackfan Anemia Foundation.

Steve Jobs' last words  He died at the age of 56 years fighting with Pancreatic Cancer and here are his last words on the sick bed: "I reached the pinnacle of success in the business world. In others’ eyes, my life is an epitome of success. However, aside from work, I have little joy. In the end, wealth is only a fact of life that I am accustomed to. At this moment, lying on the sick bed and recalling my whole life, I realize that all the recognition and wealth that I took so much pride in, have paled and become meaningless in the face of impending death. You can employ someone to drive the car for you, make money for you but you cannot have someone to bear the sickness for you. Material things lost can be found; But there is one thing that can never be found when it is lost – "Life". When a person goes into the operating room, he will realize that there is one book that he has yet to finish reading – "Book of Healthy Life". Whichever stage in life we are at right now, with time, we will face the day when the curtain comes down. Treasure Love for your family, love for your spouse, love for your friends... Treat yourself well. Cherish others. As we grow older, and hence wiser, we slowly realize that wearing a $300 or $30 watch - they both tell the same time... Whether we carry a $300 or $30 wallet/handbag - the amount of money inside is the same; Whether we drive a $150,000 car or a $30,000 car, the road and distance is the same, and we get to the same destination. Whether we drink a bottle of $300 or $10 wine - the hangover is the same; Whether the house we live in is 300 or 3000 sq ft - loneliness is the same. You will realize, your true inner happiness does not come from the material things of this world. Whether you fly first or economy class, if the plane goes down - you go down with it... Therefore.. I hope you realize, when you have mates, buddies and old friends, brothers and sisters, who you chat with, laugh with, talk with, have sung songs with, talk about north-south-east-west or heaven and earth, .... That is true happiness!! Five Undeniable Facts of Life : 1. Don't educate your children to be rich. Educate them to be Happy. So when they grow up, they will know the value of things not the price. 2. Best awarded words in London ... "Eat your food as your medicines. Otherwise you have to eat medicines as your food." 3. The One who loves you will never leave you for another because even if there are 100 reasons to give up, he or she will find one reason to hold on. 4. There is a big difference between a human being and being human. Only a few really understand it. 5. You are loved when you are born. You will be loved when you die. In between, You have to manage! NOTE: If you just want to Walk Fast, Walk Alone! But if you want to Walk Far, Walk Together! Six Best Doctors in the World 1. Sunlight 2. Rest 3. Exercise 4. Diet 5. Self Confidence and 6. Friends Maintain them in all stages of Life and enjoy a healthy life. Source : FB And Thank you for Reading …

Yes! Mourners: Scum of Shatterdown, by Jade Ripley. This is the review I posted a few different places. Disclosure: I am acquainted with Ripley and we are members of a writers' group together. Mourners is a good novella that should have been a great novel. The plot is, at its core, a love/hate letter to the Pathfinder roleplaying game (and its D&D antecedent), especially the manichaean Good-Evil/Lawful-Chaotic alignment system and the Paladin class. Anastasia (Ana) is a novice paladin sent along with her master to overthrow the Scarlet Princess, who has toppled the lawful government of the city of Shatterdown. They are greeted enthusiastically by the populace, who seem secure and prosperous, and who throw flowers at their feet. Unfortunately, they turn out too loyal to the Princess, Ainsley, and take the paladins prisoner. Shory story shorter, Ana is required to remain in Shatterdown as a member of Ainsley's inner circle, the Scum, given ironic titles: Duke, a drow knight; Contessa, a teen technomagical genius; Margrave, a pirate captain who feeds on fear (and is possibly the most evil character I've seen recently); and Sybil, a healer and the Scum's moderating force. Against her wishes, Ana is given a title too: Bishop. She meets each other Scum in turn, and each, along with Ainsley, assists in her training. She also learns about their personal history and what brought them to be "evil", a proces that leads to her questioning the utility of the system. Eventually, as was inevitable in this genre of books, a world-threatening plot is revealed and our heroes and antiheroes are required to sally forth to meet the omnicidal villains. There's also a love story in there. The book is tightly plotted and has some of the more interesting characters I've seen in a while. It avoids all of the worst traps of a first-time writer. No character is perfect (good gods they are not), but nor has Ripley overcorrected and laden them with so many flaws that one wonders why one should care about them. Cause follows effect, which in turn becomes cause; there is no serendipity or eucatastrophe to save the chararacters and they must instead save themselves. There's clearly a living world in his head, but he doesn't try to make the book an atlas. Most importantly for this book, it creates believable "evil" characters, people who could easily be the villains of your average fantasy novel or D&D campaign, but also makes it difficult to hate them and easy to root for them. There's no wondering why Ana decides to pitch in with them. Unfortunately, this is really too much to fit into 158 pages. Pacing suffers, with too many timeskips. The descriptions are a bit too spare. I said before that Ripley doesn't try to treat us to a grand tour of his world, but it would be nice to have some set pieces to contribute to themes and atmosphere, as well as to give something more to interact with besides each other. Most of all, while the characters we see are fleshed out, too many interactions—especially, to my mind, Ana's training sessions with Duke—are glossed over and so we don't get to see enough of their relationships' growth. The reader sees why, but not how. (Also, while this won't be an issue for everyone, I found it mildly jarring to spot mechanics from the Pathfinder RPG I'm familiar with. The one exception to this is Sybil's trick to keep our heroes alive during their combat with the archetypal guardian of the underworld; that was just clever. If this doesn't bother you, or you've never played D&D or Pathfinder, this won't be a problem.) Nonetheless, it is an enjoyable read that treats its characters, even—especially—the evil ones, with compassion. While I finished Mourners unsatisfied, I am looking forward to Ripley's next work. And if he happens to return to Mourners and expand it into a novel, I'll be first in line to order it.

For a girl(especially a middle class one) in Indian society the love and support of none else but parents, specially her father is very crucial. Only her parents can give her the freedom to fly or can tie her in the chains of family reputation. The upbringing is an important factor for every child, but unfortunately, in India, there are different rules and regulations for a boy and a girl. Since childhood, it is fed into their minds that boys can stay out of home till late night but girls can’t do so else the chances of getting raped/molested increases for them. That boys will have the responsibility to earn and girls have the responsibility to stay at home and run the family. Why so? Why this decision needs to be imposed to anyone? Why can’t a boy decide to run the family and a girl decide to earn the bread? Stereotypes and the fear to break them. Most of the parents can’t dare to break these stereotypes and so they keep their children also chained if they wish to fly. But hats off of to the parents who take a bold move for the sake of their children’s future ignoring chaar log kya kahenge. Recently I read following two stories which made me feel that India for sure needs such parents. Because development of a nation begins when it’s citizens are developed. Because development comes from mind not money. Story 1: There was a girl. She was a perfect marriage material and earning a decent amount at an MNC. Still she was not getting married. Why? Because she was the only child of her parents. But that was not a problem for people. The problem was that she wanted to be the support of her parents. Problem was her condition: Either she would give her half salary to her parents post her marriage.Or she would go for a court marriage so that the money her parents had saved for her marriage, could be a support to them after her marriage.And boy, even educated and well qualified people couldn’t understand that much only. Had her parents committed a crime by giving birth to a girl? Or the crime was that they didn’t gave birth to a second child just because they thought of providing a comfortable life to their only child. But for me, great are those parents who raised their only child, and that too girl, with so much love and gave her enough confidence that she can build her own path. Story 2 : There was a boy. Being a boy you have many responsibilities on your shoulders. And this boy was taught being responsible from an age when boys usually remains involved in flings and enjoyment to an extent that they almost ignore their career and keep procrastinating their duties. But his father let him explore things alone. It’s like he had to learn to ride the bicycle. His father just bought the bicycle and handed over the same to him. His father didn’t even give him the false illusion of supporting him from behind when he first sat on it. His father just told him to ride the bicycle. He was afraid of falling down. But his father advised him to get up whenever he falls down and make another attempt. His father was keeping an eye over his actions, the way he was learning to ride the bicycle in spite of falling down multiple times. Yes it was painful to see him falling down and not lending a hand for support but his father knew that lending hand once might make his son dependent over that hand for rest of his life. And that was the path a father chose to teach his son the lesson to live life. P.S→ The upbringing of children is very important in shaping their thoughts, their perception towards life. Although external factors do play an equivalent role but what impact those external factors have on you ultimately depends on what perception you have already developed. It’s like how efficiently you learn sentence formation depends on your knowledge about the alphabets of the language.

Day before yesterday (01–09–2018), I completed reading the book “Unbreakable”.It is worth a reading.This book is a sports autobiography of Manipuri Boxing Tornado “Mangte Chungneijang Mary Kom”.How she broke all the hurdles to become a boxing queen of our Mother INDIA.This book is one of the motivational factors,I have to say. Eventhough she gave birth to 3 children,she continued her boxing.That was awesome.How she won medals for our country,the various aspects of her life,how she alleviate her poverty,how her parents supported for her,how her husband protected the trust which was given by him to Mary.This book is like a “elder sister shares her story with you”.It is a must read. This girl lifted our Mother INDIA’s head high in the field of boxing.More over,she is a coach for many students.For all of them,she provided free boxing training.Many of her students won medals in National level tournament.She shared copious heart melting incidents in the book. She is not only a Mary.Of course,She is Magnificient Mary .

So, after making it to a great a college, one of the few things that I have started doing is reading books on finance. One of them being ‘Think and Grow Rich’ by Napoleon Hill. In this book, the author brings the experience of several business magnates and philanthropists who have made it really big in life. In the first chapter, the author tells us about one of the things that Mr. Thomas Edison has learned from his years of experience that “when a man really DESIRES a thing so deeply that he is willing to stake his entire future on a single turn of the wheel in order to get it, he is sure to win.” Now, on reading, this thing resonated with me so deeply. It is some thing really great and nice that I have read in a while. So, according to me, it is the nicest thing I have read recently.

Nonfiction: Just finished THE POWER OF EIGHT by Lynne McTaggart. I had read some of her previous books and got a lot out of them. ( Fav was THE FIELD ) Not long before that A THOUSAND NAMES FOR JOY by Byron Katie; in this one she uses many examples from her life to show how to dissolve mental stuck-ness. Fiction: James Corey - THE EXPANSE Novels. Am on # 4, and if you like sci-fi, just plain good narrative, this may be for you. Set in space, 200 years in the future. Amazing world-building. Fiction: Honorable Mention: THE DISUNITED STATES OF AMERICA by Harry Turtledove. Alternate History where the Constitution was never finalized, the Articles of Confederation fell apart and the states all went their own ways. Yes, some of them had armed conflict with each other.

I am reading a book name “Dear Stranger, I Know How You Feel” by Ashish Bagrecha. Basically it is a book about A Journey To Hope And Healing. I bought this book when I was going through heartbreak.  Writer have written letters to stranger(readers ofcourse) who are fighting the dark days, who are in pain, who are sad, who are facing problems in their life. This letters are About Pain, About Heartache, About Loss, About Hope, About Failure, About Success etc. They are 30 letters in total on different topic. I am on Day 9: About Identity right now. (This is my second reading though, you know quarantine days) I found each and every line from this book is so powerful that it’ll make you forget about your problems, issues for a while. It will give you strength to fight, it will give you courage to stand again. Each and every line, every letter gives you unique, meaningful and motivating message. The truth is you are at war with yourself that’s why you find youself at war with others. Above line is from the very starting of the book and you will found very beautiful poems at the starting of the each day. This book is most beautiful thing I read recently and I am reading it again. And I would love to recommend this book to everyone here. Read it atleast once. Peace.

But he is my brother, from my heart… .Relationships from the heart are always awesome, pure, sweet …before that whether it is a blood relationship or not doesn't matter.. True bonds from the heart are pure, true, unbreakable.. I am really proud of him, for being a good friend and good brother to me, for never giving up, for being the owner of a beautiful soul, which is full of love and care for others…He mentioned that,I inspire others with my writing.. . haha…I don't know whether my language is good or not…. I just read and write from the deep bottom of my heart, it gives me happiness………… .Another nice thing was a post, posted by my beloved sister on my birthday .  This was her post… . It means a lot to me.. The person in the picture is the crazy me.. (craziness uploaded).. The other nice things I read are given below…                         I am a die heart Naruto fan…. Hope this works.Thank you for reading…

So as my convo continued with my friend he told that he and his life have been locked out together during this period of lockdown. He told me the girl writes a letter to him daily and leaves besides his pillow at night. In the morning , he usually gets up very early and reads the letter while looking at her face in all its peace while sleeping. Recently my friend surprised her when he scribbled something on the letter and kept it besides her. When I asked what was there inside…he told he wrote just two lines Teri likhi harr nazam ki kasam hai mujhko.......tujhse hi toh harr rasam ki kasam hai mujhko…… He told their love is the most unique love….they are happier each day ….. and now with COVID 19 they both know exactly what they mean to each other with all their energies and attention now focussed on each other I told him…..keep your life story a secret…..as till the time you are happy nothing else matters ….. may God bless them….

Marichka Padalko's tooth came loose as she was broadcasting on the coronavirus crisis. The television presenter of Ukraine kept her poise when she suffered a dental disaster live on air. Padalko moved her hand over her mouth to move the tooth before continuing the show. Padalko as she continues the show with a tooth missing. Many viewers did not know that anything was amiss.  Footnotes: News anchor’s tooth falls out during live TV. She keeps her cool and carries on. Watch ❤❤❤ ~Sapna Kumari ✍

Today I got an forwarded watsapp message which clearly defines what the life actually is, that was the really good thing I read and its here..:, Pls share this beautiful Bhagvat Gita message with everyone, to know the meaning of life !!! A man died... When he realized it, he saw God coming closer with a suitcase in his hand. Dialogue between God and Dead Man: God: Allright son, it’s time to go. Man: why So soon? I had a lot of plans... God: I am sorry but, it’s time to go. Man: What do you have in that suitcase? God: Your belongings. Man: My belongings? You mean my things... Clothes... money... God: Those things were never yours, they belong to the Earth. Man: Is it my memories? God: No. They belong to Time. Man: Is it my talent? God: No. They belong to Circumstance. Man: Is it my friends and family? God: No son. They belong to the Path you travelled. Man: Is it my wife and children? God: No. they belong to your Heart. Man: Then it must be my body? God: No, No... It belongs to Dust. Man: Then surely it must be my Soul! God: You are sadly mistaken son. Your Soul belongs to me. Man, with tears in his eyes and full of fear, took the suitcase from God's hand and opened it... Empty... Heartbroken and tears falling down his cheeks, he asks God... Man: I never owned anything? God: That’s right. You never owned anything. Man: Then? What was mine? God: Your MOMENTS. Every moment you lived was yours. Do Good in every moment Think Good in every moment Thank God for every moment Life is just a Moment. Live it... Love it... Enjoy it...  It is the soul of BHAGVAT GITA  Thanks for scrolling.

Recently read a book Do You Think What You Think You Think? Which is writen by Juliam Baggini.Jeremy Stamgroom. It’s a book about philosophy, psychology...such as his another book, The Pig That Wants to Be Eaten. There are some thought-provoking questions about what we think: Do you think the world you see and hear is real? Is what you believe consistent? If you could design a God, what would He, She, or It be like? Tere are a dozen philosophical quizzes guaranteed to make you discover yourself. The first question answered on QUORA.

This act by a small kid, barely nine years old.  For the amount might not sound significant to many of you, but for that kid, it is her entire life savings. Goes to tell a lot about the upbringing by her parents. And, the sweet gesture by Hero cycles is icing on the cake for the kid.  What goes around, comes around. What we do to others, will come back to us manifold.

Don’t remember when I last read something interesting but let me write some things for you that is in my mind right now - You should not bother what others think about you. Their opinions do not matter If you can’t change something, there is no need to worry or get tensed about it. Worry about those things that you can change or make it better. Don’t waste your time, emotions, etc in things you have not control over Be happy. You will then be doing more good to others than being sad and spreading it Don’t dream too big that you can’t achieve and in the end do nothing. We have the tendency of dreaming too much and when we see the reality we do nothing. Instead - do something. Do something for your dream. Do something for someone Help someone and do not expect anything in return. For two reasons - 1. you will feel bad if you do not get what you expected or got something opposite to what you gave - 2. If you are expecting something in return - it is not helping but investing. Fails the whole purpose behind helping Be there in the bad times. Thats when people need people the most. Its okay not to be there in the good times but always be there during the bad time Thanks for reading through. Made me happy as well. :)

This is so so good .... these profound distinctions between Intelligence and Wisdom…. Worth reading on ... 1. Intelligence leads to arguments. Wisdom leads to settlements. 2. Intelligence is power of will. Wisdom is power OVER will. 3. Intelligence is heat, it burns. Wisdom is warmth, it comforts. 4. Intelligence is pursuit of knowledge, it tires the seeker. Wisdom is pursuit of truth, it inspires the seeker. 5. Intelligence is holding on. Wisdom is letting go. 6. Intelligence leads you. Wisdom guides you. 7. An intelligent man thinks he knows everything. A wise man knows that there is still something to learn. 8. An intelligent man always tries to prove his point. A wise man knows there really is no point. 9. An intelligent man freely gives unsolicited advice. A wise man keeps his counsel until all options are considered. 10. An intelligent man understands what is being said. A wise man understands what is left unsaid. 11. An intelligent man speaks when he has to say something. A wise man speaks when he has something to say. 12. An intelligent man sees everything as relative. A wise man sees everything as related. 13. An intelligent man tries to control the mass flow. A wise man navigates the mass flow. 14. An intelligent man preaches. A wise man reaches. Intelligence is good but wisdom achieves better results. Wishing happiest and peaceful life ….keep smiling Thanks for reading..

This incredible book from Iran, introducing me to the amazing city of Isfahan.     My Israeli friend and I looked at this country and marveled at the beauty and elegance of a culture we wish we could visit. We saw green fields and sweeping landscapes and noble architecture. We saw kindred spirits. Thank you.

I read Perfume by Patrick Suskind recently and undoubtedly it is one of the best books I have ever read. I decided to read that book after I learnt that it was Kurt Cobain’s favorite book. The story is about a genius perfumer Jean Baptiste Grenouille who hates human kind, and about his burning desire to create the best scent- a scent that can make the bearer of that scent godlike. I should not tell more about this novel but this 98 page novel is definitely worth your time. It’s nothing like you have ever read before.

Hey, there are many things that I keep reading every now and then, but I don’t remember if anything other than this, that hit me as hard and trust me I vouch that it’ll move you too, it is so positive and beautiful, do give it a read : Archita Sadhna's answer to What is the most beautiful short passage you have read ever? Have a great day !

The First Part Last by Angela Johnson. Also Yummy: The Last Days of a Southside Shorty by G. Neri and Smile by Raina Telgemeier. All of these were very good books with important messages and good characters. I tried reading Gunnerkrigg Court but couldn’t really get into it. I liked the part where the guy becomes a bird but beyond that I’d seen it all before.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Jennifer M. Skains and Edith Barber

response.answer_text: On the Come Up by Angie Thomas about an African American girl who wants to be a hip hop artist but whose mother sees college for her way out of poverty. It is set in the same world as her Number 1 best seller, The Hate U Give which was made into a movie. I predict the same will happen with this book.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Jennifer M. Skains

response.answer_text: I’m reading The Heart Goes Last by Margaret Atwood, 11–22–63 by Stephen King ( loving it!). Just finished The Secret Life of Bees by Sue Monk Kidd for the bookclub I’m in. Also reading Dorothy Allison’s Trash, and finally Suck Less: Where There’s a Willam, There’s a Way by Willam Belli. I usually have several books going at the same time. Voracious reader. So many books, so little time….

Student asked, “ who was the first Scientist?” He thought for a while and finally answered with a big smile on his face and an inner satisfaction, “Children are the first Scientist” Huge Applaud among the audience for the statement he made. The audience were quite moved and inspired with his thoughts and acknowledged quite well. He was none other than our Missileman Dr. A P J Abdul Kalam. This has been taken from the Book “Ignited Minds” written by the Dr. A P J Abdul Kalam himself to inspire young minds with a vision to see India as a developed nation with superpower capabilities.

Currently im reading a book about world war 1 it's called a World Undone the story of the Great War written by G.J Meyer. Its a really good book it gets moved up on how and why the first WorldWar started and explains the battles and the tactics that were implemented during the war.

I’m reading a great book called I am a Strange Loop by Douglas Hofstadter at the moment. It’s about how human selves are rather like mathematical paradoxes, among other things. He’s an enthusiastic and accessible writer, which makes it a great read.

I recently finished reading “Who Moved My Cheese” by Spencer Johnson. It’s a small book, but, IT’S AWESOME. It’s really fun to read and has a good story. But most importantly, it gives you some really great information which, I believe, everybody should know about.

Thanks for A2A, At present I can say reading this question seems the nice thing which I read… as it speard a sense for many to see the nice things rather being decisive with regard to a limited perception…. When one lives with the present, whatever comes to him or her in the experience is always the nice and beautiful… that's what the life is.. that which is happening in the present..

I finished Les Miserables a week ago. It is long and frustrating, but it is so beautiful. It is so sad. I love it. It is one of those books that will stick with you for the rest of your life. I also read the Graphic Novel version of the Dragonet Prophecy (I read the actual novel years ago). It was very entertaining.

I have actually. I discovered an author named Susan May. I don't normally read her genre but I gave it a shot…and I have been pleasantly surprised. The first book I read of hers drew me in hook, line, and sinker…it's called “The Troubles Keeper.” Very great story!

Yes. I have recently read the book by Ha-Joon Chang - “Economics: The User's Guide”. It was very informative and educating book. Especially, the way he used real numbers, correlations, statistics and etc. I am sure I will address this book to quote some issues more than once.

Whatever I’m reading at any given time seems to be good while I’m reading it. I just started “Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education” by John Dewey (published in 1910, I think). I really like it since it gives me a lot to think about.

I just read Where the Crawdads Sing. By Delia Owen. Its a fantastic book - her first! About a young girl (6) who is abandoned in the marsh by her family.She has to learn to survive. Its very interesting and well written. I hope you check it out! Amazon.ca: Owens, Delia: Books

Goodreads is a good place to go to look for book recommendations. I currently have the app to keep my friends and followers updated on what I have read and enjoyed or didn't like and I look at their profiles to see the same.

I work with teenagers - a fantastic book that our school is slowly putting into practice is Steven Covey’s 7 Habits of Highly Effective Teens. My own two teenagers are often quite captive when I read excerpts. It’s great discussion around the dinner table too
I have a calendar which has a quote for every day. Someday it read: NO GOD, NO PEACE. KNOW GOD, KNOW PEACE. And it felt good to read.
Quote of the Year: Before you laugh at children who believe in Santa Claus, remember there are adults who still believe in "Rahul Gandhi"
YES! I love Education by Tara Westover. Everyone should read this book to understand the power education has in opening minds!
I'm reading The Goldfinch now and enjoying it. Or, anything by Barbara Kingsolver is always wonderful and somehow timely. As for poetry, I highly recommend Jane Mead.

Just finished Sherman Alexie’s The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-time Indian. This blew me away and I will recommend it to my bookclub at our next meeting.
Yes I just read Thus spoke Zarathustra, it was fantastic and I highly recommend it if you enjoy philosophy!
